author: Adam Kruszewski
message: Also a nice and light alternative: Gogs (https://gogs.io/). A single binary, lightweight git hosting environment. Works great and I think it is a half-way between full fledged GitLab and a bare bones gitolite. I'm not affiliated with Gogs, I'm just a very satisfied user as I use it on a cheap vps to host my own personal projects.

author: Kevin Funk
message:
Brillant article. Exactly my thoughts about the recent "GitHub bashing"... Let's make this one thing clear: The GitHub UX is just light-years ahead of other comparable solutions, that's what makes people use the service without a lot of consideration.

If you do want to *own* your data: Do the hosting yourself (and accept *all* the inherent problems you get with it (additional maintenance needs for the systems, reduced accessibility for outsiders), your choice. Let's face it: Your project doesn't get less contributions if you don't use GitHub. The barrier to contribute to random projects (not hosted on well-known hosting platforms) isn't raised by the existence of GitHub. It's as high (or low) as before.

GitHub really isn't the problem, there are plenty of other solutions where to host your project. You decide what's best for your project.

replies.author: Colin
replies.message:
> Your project doesn't get less contributions if you don't use GitHub

This isn't always true. Did you read the ESLint quote in this article? As a programmer, I didn't start contributing to open source software until 5~6 after I began programming. It was intimidating. I've learned Github now, so I'm comfortable checking out code and submitting patches there. I've filed a single patch to a project on Sourceforge, though I doubt I did it correctly because IIRC it was basically a giant .diff attached to an issue report. I was fortunate that this was a small project, but if I had filed my patch incorrectly to a different project, there are plenty of cases in which I would have been shouted at.

That's in no way a problem of the host. But it means that I'm more likely to stick with what I know, rather than risk trying to learn a new platform only to use it incorrectly and have the risk of being yelled at.

Furthermore, when you're searching for projects to use and/or contribute to, where do you search? A Google search with no filter won't likely give you many results. A DuckDuckGo search with "!github" will give you very relevant results. Until there's a filter group, like "!opensource" that would search Github, Gitlab, Sourceforge, etc, your project will likely get less visibility, and thus fewer contributors, if you host it somewhere else than Github.

But again, this is no fault of Github's. It's exactly the issue that this article was touching on.

author: Martin Drapeau
message:
For an enterprise, GitHub offers you powerful features and a lot of convenience for very little money. The ROI is incredible. For a team of developers, it has revolutionized how we develop code together. Code reviews become a breeze. For a developer, GitHub is your resume, like LinkedIn for is for suits. It also offers you a powerful tool for personal projects with inexpensive private repos in the cloud. You can even host your blog and personal webpage on GitHub for free. In addition, GitHub has become the backbone of the open source community. It lets developers shine and makes it so simple for anyone to get involved with little friction.

On GitHub there are no ads and everything is fast and reliable. Its actually quite impressive how fast it is, and how efficient everything you do is. The only thing I feel is lacking is good project management all starting with Issues. That may evolve over time based on feedback provided by the community. Ideas like issue templates is a good step forward. I just don't want to see MS Project or JIRA cloned into it. So GitHub, do take your time on that front. I'm not in a hurry.

I do love GitHub. And I'm all in for alternatives. At this point, I do not see the benefit of switching.

author: Lamont Granquist
message:
I don't think its "arrogant" at all. Open Source contributors are already working for free. I don't think its unreasonable for them to desire that GitHub contribution history that prospective employers can look at. The poster there has a perfectly valid point about losing an incentive to contribute if the project moves off GitHub.

Don't shoot the messenger.

replies.author: Aurélien Gâteau
replies.message: I don't know about you, but when I contribute to a project, I do it because I want to fix a bug or add a feature. Building a reputation around my contribution is just a nice side-effect. So yes, I find it arrogant to say "if you leave GitHub, I won't contribute anymore because I can't brag about my contributions". Furthermore, you can still brag about your contributions anyway: nothing prevents you from linking to work on a resume, even if they are not hosted on GitHub, or write about them on a blog. The only thing you miss is the list of repositories you forked.

replies.author: Lamont Granquist
replies.message: And I find you to be arrogant for having a purity test for open source contributions that you measure others against.
